title: 110_s2455
content:
The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additional emergency CDBG funding is addressed in the Act. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for foreclosure-related assistance under the community development block grant program, including rental assistance for individual renters affected by foreclosures. Counseling services are exempt from this funding limitation. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for foreclosure-related assistance under the community development block grant program, including rental assistance for individual renters in the form of relocation assistance. Funds cannot be used for homeowner foreclosure prevention purposes, except for counseling services, which can be provided to certified housing counseling services approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The term "certified housing counseling service" refers to a housing counseling agency approved by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 3. INCREASED PUBLIC SERVICES REQUIREMENT CAP.

This Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25% for all funds provided under it.

SEC. 4. LOW AND MODERATE INCOME REQUIREMENT.

At least 50% of the funds under this Act must primarily benefit low- and moderate-income individuals.

SEC. 5. PLANS AND REPORTS. SEC. 5. PLANS AND REPORTS.

Funds under this Act must benefit low- and moderate-income individuals. States, cities, or counties must submit a comprehensive plan for fund use and report quarterly on expenditures. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive certain provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds, excluding fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and environmental requirements. Waivers must align with the overall purpose of the statute. Additionally, the Secretary may waive the 50 percent requirement upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive certain provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate fund use, aligning with the overall purpose of the statute. Waivers for the 50 percent requirement and public service cap may be granted upon request from a State, metropolitan city, or urban county if a compelling need is demonstrated. Waivers must be published in the Federal Register. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development can waive certain provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate fund use, aligning with the overall purpose of the statute. Waivers may be granted if a compelling need is demonstrated and must be published in the Federal Register. Waivers granted under this section will be reconsidered and reauthorized by the Secretary every two years. The Secretary must also notify the Committee on Appropriations of the Senate and the Committee on. The waiver process involves notifying the Senate and House Committees on Appropriations of any granted or denied waivers at least 5 days before the decision is made. SEC. 7. Noncompliance with community development requirements under this Act will be subject to the provisions of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8. The Comptroller General will conduct an audit of all funds appropriated under this Act and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees. SEC. 9. Reports will be required as part of the oversight process. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must provide quarterly reports to the Senate and House Committees on the use of funds, including counseling and rental assistance details, certified housing counseling services, and efforts to prevent fraud and abuse.
